SENT.plain: Craniosynsostosis syndromes exhibit considerable phenotypic and genetic heterogeneity
Sagittal synostosis is common form of isolated craniosynostosis
The sutures involved, the shape of the skull and associated malformations give a clue to the specific diagnosis
Crouzon syndrome is one of the most common of the craniosynostosis syndromes
Apert syndrome accounts for 4.5% of all craniosynostoses and is one of the most serious of these syndromes
Most syndromic craniosynostosis require multidisciplinary management
The following review provides a brief appraisal of the various genes involved in craniosynostosis syndromes, and an approach to diagnosis and genetic counseling
